properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will give blizzard conditions over these areas beginning this morning. Conditions should gradually improve overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow are expected. A strong Pacific storm will bring 30 to 60 cm of snow over inland sections of the north coast. Snow will continue today over the inland sections of the north coast. The snow is expected to ease and become mixed with rain tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T16:43:21-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A winter storm will continue to spread snow to the B.C. Peace and Fort Nelson regions tonight. Additional snowfall accumulations near 10 cm are forecast tonight for Fort Nelson and the areas near the Rockies, including Chetwynd and Hudson Hope. Lesser amounts are expected elsewhere. Snow should end early Saturday morning for the Peace region and will continue through midday Saturday near Fort Nelson. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T16:22:25-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and wind expected beginning Sunday afternoon. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Stronger coastal gusts possible. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across eastern Newfoundland Sunday afternoon. Strong winds and blowing snow will develop overnight Sunday and continue into Monday morning. Snow and blowing snow will result in poor visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Conditions are expected to improve near noon Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-04T18:24:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T02:25:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3157634076.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected on Sunday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm, possibly higher over parts of the eastern mainland and Cape Breton Time span: Before dawn Sunday morning into Sunday night. Location: all of Nova Scotia Remarks: A disturbance will approach the Maritimes later tonight and spread snow to much of the province. In the west and along parts of the Atlantic coast, the precipitation will start as rain and then change to snow early Sunday morning. At this time, the highest amounts are expected over eastern sections of the province where the snow will persist into the evening. General snowfall amounts of 5 to 15 cm are expected, with locally higher amounts possible over easter regions. However, should the intensity or track of this system shift from what is currently expected, these amounts could change. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop later on Sunday, especially over the eastern half of the province, and combine with the fresh snow to create reduced visibility in blowing snow. The combination of snow and blowing snow could impact travel in parts of the province later on Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T00:42:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T08:43:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3913517125.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme windchill values of -50 to -55 are expected through the weekend. Some moderation may occur during the day. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h beginning Sunday evening with stronger coastal gusts possible. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: 2 to 5 cm of snow can be expected across southeastern Newfoundland Sunday afternoon. The snow will become heavy in the evening with significant accumulations expected. Strong winds and blowing snow will develop Sunday evening and continue into Monday morning. Snow and blowing snow will result in poor visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Conditions are expected to improve near noon Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A strong Pacific storm will move through the region tonight and Saturday. Rain will begin falling on the Coquihalla Highway this evening and then quickly transition to snow by late evening. Snow heavy at times will fall through the night before easing slightly on Saturday. The snow is expected to change over to a few flurries Saturday evening. A total of 20 to 30 cm of snow is possible depending on how quickly the transition from rain to snow occurs, ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T16:23:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T00:24:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3634202335.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will continue to give snow to Williston and Highway 97 - Pine Pass this evening. Snow near Mackenzie may become mixed with rain this evening as temperatures rise. However, snow at Pine Pass will persist overnight. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 15 cm can be expected by Saturday morning with highest amounts near Pine Pass. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T13:59:53-00:00

Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A frontal system moving across the interior is giving southerly winds 70 gusting to 90 km/h to the southern sections of Fraser Canyon. The winds may ease somewhat this evening but strong winds may redevelop overnight. The winds are expected to abate early Saturday morning as the front moves away from the region. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure centre crossing the North Coast is bringing a period of heavy snow to the Stewart region. 5 cm has been received as of 4pm. Snow is intensifying this evening, and 15 cm is expected to fall through the evening and overnight. A total of 15 to 20 cm new snow will be on the ground by Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
